Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Electrophysiological responses to violations of verb argument structure in Spanish-English bilinguals' first language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bilingual speakers make up a large portion of the population, both in the U.S. and abroad. Their two languages are not completely compartmentalized in the bilingual brain and mind, but rather the languages interact in dynamic ways. It is still unclear, however, whether learning a second language can affect one's native language, and if so, to what extent. Previous research has shown that certain grammatical constructions are strongly linked in the two languages of bilingual speakers. What about grammatical constructions that exist in only one of the two languages? Evidence that a construction which exists only in the second-learned language can be used to interpret sentences in the native language would provide strong support for an integrated grammatical system in bilinguals and one that is affected by new experiences.

This project takes advantage of a grammatical difference between Spanish and English. In English, manner-of-motion verbs such as 'run' and 'jump' can be used to describe an event in which someone causes another person (or being) to carry out the action. For example, in the sentence "The trainer jumped the horse over the fence," the trainer causes the action to occur, but it is the horse that performs the action of jumping. In Spanish, these same verbs ('correr' [run] and 'saltar' [jump]) cannot be used to describe causative actions; constructions of this type are ungrammatical (and uninterpretable in a causative sense).

The study will investigate whether native Spanish speakers who have learned English can interpret these ungrammatical sentences in Spanish due to their knowledge of English. To investigate whether age of second language acquisition or language dominance are important factors, early versus late acquirers of English will be compared, as well as speakers who are more proficient in Spanish versus those more proficient in English. Finally, to determine whether processing of these structures occurs automatically or only after conscious application of linguistic rules, the study includes electrophysiological measures (event-related potentials) and judgments of sentence acceptability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dissertation project carried out by Eve Higby investigated the way that bilinguals access linguistic information in both of their languages. Prior work has shown that bilinguals’ languages are constantly available even in a monolingual context and that mental representations for grammatical constructions that exist in both languages may be shared rather than stored separately. The project investigated whether grammatical constructions that exist in only the second-learned language are also accessible when listening to sentences in the first-learned language. Moreover, the project investigated whether the age at which the second language is learned affects the degree to which the languages interact.

 

Using electrophysiological measures to capture online sentence comprehension processes, we found that Spanish-English bilinguals were able to process grammatically incorrect sentences in Spanish that would be grammatically correct if translated into English. Spanish speakers with limited English proficiency showed similar brain responses for the critical sentences as they did for other types of ungrammatical constructions, indicating that these sentences were not easy for them to comprehend. These findings indicate that bilinguals are able to employ their grammatical knowledge to understanding novel sentences in either language. This supports previous theories proposing an integrated system of grammatical knowledge in the bilingual mind and extends it to include grammatical knowledge that is unique to one language.

 

Another important finding from this research was that bilinguals who learned English at early ages or in adolescence both showed this ability to flexibly use their grammatical knowledge when listening to Spanish sentences. This finding has important implications for theories of neural plasticity, specifically as they relate to language acquisition and processing. Language researchers and language educators often assume that the native language does not change after a certain point in development. The research reported here challenges that view by showing that the native language of bilinguals is subject to influence from the second-learned language, even when learning begins in the teenage years.

 

The research has both theoretical and practical implications. First, by using electrophysiological measures, it provides critical new evidence of how the bilingual grammatical system operates in real-time, contributing to our scientific understanding of language processing and representations and allows us to build better theories of neural plasticity for language. This has implications for several different fields of study: linguistics, psychology, cognitive science, and brain research. Second, the project has provided critical training in neurophysiological research methodology for the doctoral awardee, but also for a group of eleven undergraduate and post-graduate research assistants who come from underrepresented groups in science (women and Hispanics). Six of these research assistants have since been accepted into graduate schools.
